charity.description:
At Macmillan, we will move mountains to help people with cancer live life as fully as they can.

We’re doing whatever it takes. But without your help we can’t support everyone who needs us. To
donate, volunteer, raise money or campaign with us, call 0300 1000 200 or visit macmillan.org.uk
charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
During February, I've committed to walking an average of 9,000 steps each day, in aid of MacMillan Cancer Support.  This has involved dragging kids and friends out during lockdown - thank you to those who have joined me for a stomp and a chat around Keynsham! 

Macmillan gives people with cancer everything they’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are their worries. They are doing whatever it takes. But without your help they can’t support everyone who needs them. Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

Please give whatever you can - even if just a couple of quid! - to this awesome charity.

Thanks so much

Hels Bels x

Starting at 8 pm on Friday night 5th March and finishing at 4 pm on Sunday 7th, we will hopefully have run/walk four miles 12 times.  Not sure how the two 4 AM starts are going to go but we will give it our all.

Any spare change will be gratefully received, Macmillan were there when I needed them and hopefully, they will be around if you need their assistance.


Thank you xx

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Thank you for taking the time out to support my Spring Bake Sale and helping me raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support 💐🧁

This Mother's Day, I wanted to honour my beautiful Aunty and Granny, and all those who have unfortunately lost their battle to Cancer.

Both women were so strong, caring, loving and kind. They'd never fail to put a smile on your face and were always there in times of need. They adored my passion for baking and always encouraged me, by trying all my different bakes. This is what makes baking so special to me. It reminds me of the love it can bring - especially when you're missing someone special.

So for each sale made during the month of March by my small business - Brownies by Fatima. I will be donating a percentage of it to Mcmillan Cancer Support 💚 to thank them for all the support and love they offered my family and many other families, throughout the difficult process of losing a loved one. 


"One brownie at a time, we can make this possible" 🍫🏆

story:
Eight members of our staff are going to walk, run, cycle and swim throughout March the length of the UK from Lands End to John O'Groats, raising money for Macmillan Cancer Support.

All donations are greatly received and we will be keeping everyone update on our progress as we move along.

Thank you.

Omega Security Systems LTD

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
As some of you may know our family has had some sad news this year of our grandad being diagnosed with terminal cancer. From the beginning we have been given the support of the cancer nurse who is available 24/7 for all members of the family. She isn’t just there to help with the medical side either, she’s there if we want to talk, have any confusing questions, and to support and reassure us of the future. 

We decided that we wanted to give back to help fund the ongoing support for families including our own during their fight with cancer, as well as future families that require the help and support to get to grips and understand what their diagnosis means.

Both of us are keen walkers and have been for years, but thanks to the coronavirus we’ve let our physical activity slip to almost nothing. So we thought why not kick start ourselves again by walking a marathon for cancer support! It’s gonna be hot, and long, and super sweaty in the July sun, but all the hard work will be worth it to support such an amazing charity. 

Thanks for taking the time to read through our story, and here’s a little bit about Macmillan and JustGiving written by the website: 

 At Macmillan, we give people with cancer everything we’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are our worries. We’re doing whatever it takes. But without your help we can’t support everyone who needs us.Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Hey! Thanks for checking out my page and supporting my fundraising. 

I will (hopefully, Covid dependent) be running the Great North Run in aid of the charity Macmillan, which does amazing work all over the country, providing support to those who are battling cancer, and their families too. 

This charity is a particularly important one to me and my family and has been paramount in supporting us through some challenging times, especially over the last few years, with my dad and auntie both using their services. 

With this fundraiser, I hope to raise money for Macmillan to allow them to continue providing love, support, and reassurance to those diagnosed with cancer, and those who are struggling with a loved-ones diagnosis. The charity works directly with cancer patients, providing them with information, health care, and financial support during the most challenging time in their life. It also campaigns for better awareness of cancer, striving to provide better cancer care and to find new treatments for future generations. 

As most of you know, I am a keen runner, (albeit having been off injured for 2 months), so unlike my GNR debut back in 2019, this may be slightly more challenging! Having said this, I'm excited to take on a new challenge, especially as it'll give me something to aim for during this relatively boring time! I have also just invested in a spin bike (cliché I know), so I'm aiming to cycle 300km every month too, along with a few 10km races later in the year! 

Any donations and support will be greatly appreciated! 

Thank you,

Claire xxxx

Every year, more than 400,000 people learn how to save a life through our training programmes.
Our volunteers provide first aid in their communities and thanks to them fewer lives will be lost needlessly. 
Raise money. Help save lives. Be the difference.
charity.name: St John Ambulance
eventName: Luke’s bike ride to and from school everyday for a month
story:
This spring, spring clean your health and home to support St John Ambulance 

Springis the season of new beginnings for all. It is slowly getting warmer; the grass is getting a bit greener and the air feels a bit fresher. It is the perfect time of year to have a clean out and to get out! So this Spring why not Spring into Action for St John Ambulance and support our volunteers as they continue to step forward to give vital support to those in need across the country. 
 
Since the beginning of the COVID-19 outbreak our volunteers have given an incredible number of hours of support to patients in hospitals across the country, and we are not stopping. Throughout Spring we are continuing to mobilise thousands of volunteers to support the rollout of the COVID-19 vaccination. 
 
We need funds to maintain our activities supporting the NHS in our COVID-19 response. The emergency is on-going, and our volunteers will continue to step forward to give vital support. The work we deliver in our com
title: Spring into Action

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
BHF’s work is very close to home for me as they continue to do research in to heart diseases, strokes and vascular dementia. After having some scares with older family members within the past couple of years,  I’ve decided to try and raise funds for BHF as, like a lot of charities, Covid has forced them to reduce their fundraising and led to them having to cut their 2020 research budget in half. 

For anyone who knows me, they know how much I love chocolate and sugar so this isn’t going to be an easy challenge, but any support is appreciated!! Thank you!
title: Dechox Challenge for British Heart Foundation

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
eventName: 100 miles in March for the British Heart Foundation
story:
Hello! Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support.

Recently one of my closest friends lost a relative in relation to a heart problem, I am going to be walking 100 miles throughout March and would be super grateful if you could donate as little or as much as you possibly can to help towards this amazing charity.

 The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

story:
Thanks for visiting our team fitbugs.net page. We are raising money for the British Heart Foundation and are so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help us hit our target. Thank you so much!

We will be completing a distance challenge on March 21st, with team members choosing from a 5km to a half marathon. We also have the Alphabet challenge running for the whole month. In the current circumstances the team will either be solo or in pairs. 

Let's do this team and raise funds and awareness!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
eventName: The TCM Group's 2021 Fundraising Partnership with the British Heart Foundation
story:
The TCM Group has made the decision to form an ongoing charity partnership relationship with two charities, in celebration of our 20th anniversary year, during 2021. The British Heart Foundation is one of our chosen causes, and we are also supporting Alzheimer's Society.

The British Heart Foundation carry out lifesaving research and support for heart patients. Heart and circulatory diseases remain the world's biggest killers, but the recent pandemic has cut the charity's future research ambitions in half. As their progress slows, millions of lives are being put at further risk.

Research carried out by the BHF has developed machines that can restart hearts, the ability to fix arteries in tiny babies and the power to donate a heart from one individual to another. Over 7 million people in the UK live with heart conditions, and devastatingly, 1 in 4 die from heart and circulatory disease. We hope that our efforts as an organisation, alongside the support of our customers, connections and friends, will ensure that crucial ongoing research can continue, in the light of the financial uncertainty that recent times have delivered.

As an organisation, we plan to raise funds through a number of means:

- We will be making a £20 donation, split across our two chosen causes, for each Mediation Service we deliver, and for every place booked on our National Certificate in Workplace Mediation open-access training courses.

- We run regular webinars and conferences to promote our products and services. For each of these free events, we will be suggesting that attendees make a suggested donation of £5 to their choice of our two partner charities.

- We plan to run fundraising activities, challenges and events to offer further opportunity for our wider team to get involved and raise additional funds throughout the year.
title: TCM's 2021 Fundraising Partnership with The British Heart Foundation

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Kier Group has selected the British Heart Foundation, the biggest independent funder of cardiovascular research in the UK, as its new corporate charity partner. The two-year partnership will help in the charitys aim of increasing awareness of cardiovascular disease, raise £250,000 for vital research in to heart and circulatory conditions as well as train 1,500 Kier colleagues in the lifesaving first aid, CPR.

The British Heart Foundation is funding life saving research to help end heartbreak for the seven million people in the UK living with cardiovascular disease. For over 50 years it has pioneered research that has transformed the lives of people living with heart and circulatory conditions and has been pivotal to offering vital treatments that are changing the fight against heart disease.
title: Kier Group and the British Heart Foundation partnership

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story: My Step Challenge is a fun and simple way to raise money for the BHF. With every pound you raise and your support, we will be closer to beating heartbreak forever. I've chosen this challenge for a number of reasons. My husband had a heart attack just before Christmas, which thankfully he is recovering from; a friend's family is touched by a hereditary heart condition and I have seen the distress this causes; and last but not least to motivate me, increase my fitness and my heart health.

Anyone is welcome to join in and support us and we thank you all for your donations and support.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
I have a lot
to be thankful to the British Heart Foundation for. My son was born 6 weeks prematurely
in November 1995 with a congenital heart disorder called Transposition of the
Great Artery, it was quickly diagnosed and he had surgery at 10 days old and
after a month in hospital we got him home. He has regular checkups and we are
delighted that so far he has had no need of further intervention.

I myself
have had 3 heart attacks in the last 14 years with the last one being in
February 2019 when I was finally diagnosed with a condition called Spontaneous Coronary
Artery Dissection  (SCAD) Spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD)
is when a tear appears in the wall of a coronary artery, which supplies blood
to your heart.

In June of 2020 my mother was diagnosed with vascular dementia and heart
failure.

These are only the heart and circulatory diseases issues which affect my immediate
family, but it affects around 7.6 million people in the UK alone. A large
proportion of the funding for research, treatment and nursing staff comes from
groups like BHF, even here on our little Island there are hundreds of people whose
lives have changed dramatically because of the occasional pennies we have thrown
in buckets at a bag pack or put into the little red box sitting on the counter
in our local shops.

So for the month of March I am giving up chocolate,  crisps and sweets to help raise money for BHF

story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
In October 2020 my brother in law sadly passed away at a very young age due to an hereditary heart condition called AVRC. He was taken way too soon and left a huge hole in many many people’s hearts! So I’ve decided to give up all things chocolate throughout March! And anyone that knows me knows that’s a massive thing for me!  As I love  chocolate 🍫 Anything to raise money for such a good cause to stop this happening to other people in the future. 


The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
I chose this charity as not only is it close to my heart having family & friends affected and lost loved ones it's also a massive silent killer heart disease and often no signs at all, I'd appreciate just £1 of your money to raise vital funds for a very worthy cause,
12,500 steps a day may seem easy to you and usually would to me but as I'm 6 weeks post op from a foot op this is a challenge for me as every step I take still hurts,believe me if I could run I would be doing but in the near future I'll be back running and raising even more funds
Thanks for reading ,thanks if you can donate but if not please give me a share much love
title: Dawn's Half a million steps

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

A little about the heart foundation follows....... The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
In March 2011 former M.O.T!ON co-promoter and our very dear friend 'Mark Jamison' (Jamo to his friends) suddenly passed away in his sleep. Jamo died at the age of 41, his death was caused by a very rare heart condition, to which if known could have been treated. This event we dedicated to him, this is our way of remembering the true gent Jamo was and also a celebration of his life.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Please help me to raise funds for the BHF. 

About 10 years ago, I experienced a small stroke and needed a small heart operation. I was very "lucky" in the sense that the longterm consequences have so far been minor regarding my own health.

So many others need support due to heart illness and BHF supports this.

I am giving up sugar for a month -  no cakes, desserts, confectionery etc. It's a smallish challenge, but those who know me know how hard I find it to say no to chocolate! 

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
As you know I've had a few bumps in the road these past few years and, in part, it's thanks to the research of the BHF that I've been able to benefit from amazing advances in medicine and surgery:

I've had (4) heart surgeries without needing a 'zipper' down my front. Amazing!

I've an implanted defibrillator - which is barely noticeable - and can be interrogated by the electrophysiologists in Leeds without my leaving the front door.

I can do an ECG - while laid in bed!

Who knows what other amazing treatments are out there waiting to be found - without research and funding we will never know.

So, if the work of the BHF is close to your heart, perhaps my posting this has just given you a little nudge to make a donation  (how about that £2.50 you've saved from brewing your own coffee at home) and by doing so, to help make the future for all heart patients, that little bit brighter.

Note from the BHF:

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

eventName: In memory of Michael Anthony Lye
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

In 2008 Michael's grand-daughter, Teegan, was born with a hole in her heart.  Teegan has spent the last 13 years under the care of the Royal Brompton Hospital and had to undergo her first operation at just the tender age of 4 months. Teegan has had a number of operations throughout her life.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Hello,

Your probably  wondering why I have a picture of my daughter as my cover photo. You see she is the reason I’m alive today and will continue to be for many many years to come because I’ve decided to make a lifestyle change and fix my unhealthy ways. After being diagnosed pre diabetic A result of suffering from a binge eating disorder from mental health issues and problems, I made a choice that if I continue down this road I won’t see her grow into a beautiful woman, I will miss her milestones achievements and life. That scared me into reality and I’m determined to choose life and fight back against my obstacles. 

I chose this charity as I sadly lost both my grandads far to early in their lives on the date the 8th of October, at exactly the same time, both from heart failure ten years apart. They both had their own personal issues my Grandad Starr  suffered with stress due to his line of work  & my Granddad Travers had diabetes alongside  Underlying issues which resulted in their precious hearts stopping and our families broken something I’m not going to let happen. 

My vice is chocolate & junk food. So I’ve decided to give it all up not just for 31 days, that’s a first step. I want to kick it to the kerb for good. I’m Pre diabetic, weighing in at 16 stone and suffering from, sciatica, pcos, leg cramps and breathlessness all avoidable and self inflicted. Putting strain on my body and heart that can be changed now. Last year in lockdown I took a real dive in life I’m diagnosed with a  borderline personality disorder and attempted suicide, fell into depression and my binge eating spiralled out of control.

 I know both my grandads are near and are with me everyday as I find white feathers often around my home. They would be so upset and telling me make the change. NOW

I want to raise money for BHF and thought in doing so can also get myself healthy and change my own habits for a healthier heart and lifestyle. Whilst fitting the memory of them

£1 to £10 or more please donate today to raise money so we can save lives and fix hearts xx 


Thankyou
title: Kerry's 31 day and beyond Dechox
rememberedPersonSummary.name: My Grandads  Starr/Travers
pageSummary: I am dechoxing because It’s time to make a change for others and myself.
pageSummaryWhy: It’s time to make a change for others and myself.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story:

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
I lost a family member suddenly to a heart attack shortly before Christmas last year. Jeremy this is for you. 😇

I have already gone a couple of weeks without chocolate now, as I gave it up for lent (since 17th Feb). Anyone who knows me knows how much I love chocolate....plus my birthday is this month, so this is an extra difficult challenge for me! 😩🥺

I have done this before (it doesn’t get any easier!!) but given the personal connection to the BHF charity this year, I decided to sign up for this challenge officially. I am not expecting much from this, but any small donation would be appreciated massively 😀 thank you 🍫

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
I'm giving up chocolate and sweets for the month of March to raise money for the British Heart Foundation - a charity which is very dear to my heart. I wouldn't normally trouble you for sponsorship but if you know how much I love chocolate you'll appreciate what a huge challenge this is going to be for me, so I'm going to need your sponsorship to boost my motivation!

I lost two people very close to my heart due to heart conditions. The pain of losing them is what nightmares are made of. However, the British Heart Foundation is such an important charity and the research they carry out could change other people’s lives for the better in the future.

Any amount will be gratefully received and provide a quantum of encouragement. My mum will be policing me and if I cheat, I will match all your donations.

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
After a very strange difficult year in 2020, I know how lucky I am to be fit & healthy & looking forward to better times for my family, friends & colleagues in 2021. I intend to do this challenge every year, but always miss the start date, so this year is different! Last night I ate my last piece of chocolate & signed up. 

My dad died 36 years ago through heart disease and the work of BHF helps prevent many daughters losing their Dads at a young age. This pandemic is the biggest challenge BHF has faced its 60 year history & has led it to being forced to make the devastating decision to cut the research budget in half. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. 

Please sponsor me & help support the BHF, thank you

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge for all of us, and charities are struggling. It has led to BHF being forced to make the devastating decision to cut their 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, they’ve never needed our support more. 

I am thrilled that Mark and our two boys are doing this challenge with me to remember my Mam in such a good way to support the BHF. 

We lost my mam when I was 20 (she was 53).  She never met Mark, she never got to know the joy of  knowing our boys. When he was younger, my eldest once said he missed not knowing what her voice sounded like! (Brought a tear to my eye, I don’t mind telling you). 

Your donation will help so many children know what their grandparents sound like and to have lovely memories of time spent with them. 

Thankyou, Pamela x

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
For anyone who knows me well, you will know that I am an absolute choc addict - I would happily ditch all food groups and live on Nomo/Dairy Milk until I eat myself into a sugar coma. No matter how aware I am of my sugar addiction I haven't been able to stop, and it has taken a massive toll on my health and wellbeing. For the month of march my body is a chocolate/sweet free zone (can someone check my temperature?!)


Now is as good a time as any to take control and though the incentive will start this, the pathway to better physical and mental health will keep me going. It’s not forever, but perhaps moderation will arise from the ashes of depravation. Please excuse my obnoxiously privileged melodrama.


BHF are doing great things to support those suffering with heart conditions, as well as offering advice to help everyone look after their health during the pandemic. If you are able then I’d love if you could donate to BHF through my justgiving page, if you aren’t then I’d love to hear what your favourite healthy swaps are, or just a catch up, these are lonely times and it’s easy to neglect our social selves.

 
See you in April, when I *might* be found curled up in an easter egg foaming at the mouth (but hopefully not!)

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
As some of you may know I lost my brother Sammy in 2018, in part due to a heart condition he had.

in 2019 I ran the Wigan 10k, last year I was unable to do so due to Covid so I am planning 24 Hours of Gaming in aid of BHF, somewhat less active but still giving it a go.  Plus Sammy lasted 30 minutes max on a PlayStation before getting bored, figured this is something I could definitely beat him at.

Serious part though, I imagine BHF, like many other charities, have been hit hard by the pandemic so any support is great.

I plan on raising £240 over 24 hours, any support is massively appreciated, whether it's donating, sharing, gaming along with me or watching/commenting on the stream, all links below.

PSN - TimmyLeah

Activision - Timmmmahhh

Twitch - https://www.twitch.tv/timmyleah

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target.
title: Tim's 24 Hours of Gaming

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story:
Those of you that know my family will remember my Grandad Stan, AKA Grandad Stumpy AKA Stanislaw Glinski. He was a lovely man and we lost him too soon  to heart disease, so I’d like to help raise some money to prevent others from losing a family member too soon.


 The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Both Lottie & Lizzie have decided to give up all chocolatey goods for the month of March to raise money for the British Heart Foundation, one of many charities who have been severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. 

BHF story: The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

Please support us this month in aid of a great cause! It's definitely going to be challenging during tea breaks!! 

Thank you!! Lizzie & Lottie xxx

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic has hit everyone hard and particularly charities such as British Heart Foundation

I am doing this for two reasons; 1. To raise money for this worthy charity and 2. To save myself from potential heart issues which could put further strain on the NHS and this charity!

I have gained a lot of weight over the last few years and quite honestly it wouldn’t hurt me to give up the chocolate for 31 days!!! As hard as this will be I’d love to raise money whilst helping myself become healthier and fitter, I’m a total chocoholic so donating to this cause will motivate me and give me the drive to keep at it

So, throw some money this way, if I raise £75 I get a lovely medal but ideally I’d love to reach £200 for them

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Those of you who know us will also be aware of how much Siobhan and I (Alison) both like our chocolate and therefore how much of a challenge this will be!

Both of us have people within our families and friends who have needed heart consultants over the years, be it for holes in the heart, heart attacks or other specialist heart treatment. 

For Siobhan, her niece was born with 3 holes in her heart and recently her friend's granddaughter was born during lockdown with a hole in her heart.

For Alison, her dad has had 2 major heart attacks and had heart surgery to fit a stent (to keep an artery open). They nearly lost him on the operating table! One of my friends had a daughter during lockdown and in January had open heart surgery to repair a hole in her heart after she went into heart failure.

Without the research undertaken by BHF all of these situations could have had very different outcomes.

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
I’ve done this every year, this charity is very close to my heart. I think it’s very important that we all cut back on sugar, could you give up chocolate for a month? It is a really tough challenge and it really does test you and if you would like to donate then great, if not it’s not a problem 🤗

I’m just doing it for my own health. I will take measurements before and afterwards just to see the difference, I will let you know the results at the end of it all. 

Wish me luck, I will need it 😆

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Once again embarking on my annual journey of giving up chocolate for 28-31 days (this year is the full 31!) in line with the British Heart Foundation's Dechox fundraising scheme. Having been diagnosed with pulmonary stenosis as a child--and having since been given the all-clear as of 2012--and possessing a family history of heart conditions, this cause and organisation means a lot to me. See the BHF story below:

This pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.
title: BHF Dechox Round 3 - March 2021

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
When Jay did a charity gaming stream, I wanted to fund-raise too. I found a great cause in British Heart Foundation, whose research budget was cut in half in 2020. Every donation helps raise money towards research for heart and circulatory diseases - the world's biggest killers. 

As you all know, I have an incredibly sweet tooth and I went for the biggest challenge: no chocolate, sweets or fizzy drinks for a month!

Wish me luck!

story: I have decided to give up chocolate again (for the month of March) to help this excellent cause. As most of you probably know I’m a complete chocoholic, so this is no easy challenge! I also suffer with a heart condition and this charity has given me excellent advice and support. All charities are suffering due to the pandemic so hopefully by giving up chocolate I can help this charity a little bit.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: Anyone that knows me knows i have a massive sweet tooth. I love all things chocolate, sweets and cakes. We tend to make baked goods in our house every week without fail!!!! So this is going to be a real toughy for me (especially a serial snacker hubby who kindly sits next to me scoffing) but i am going to cut all of this out for the whole of March and hopefully raise some money in the process (i mean if i could lose a few lbs at the same time i wouldn't complain). I have people close to me that have had family and friends with heart problems and seen first hand how hard it is to deal with. So if you could donate anything big or small it would be greatly appreciated and i will keep you updated with my progress. Thank you, much love xxxx

story:

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The BHF has had to cut research grants due to the pandemic. Funds are needed to support the ongoing research.

As an obese middle aged woman I need to start taking responsibility for my health, so the  dechox challenge will help me to do that whilst raising  valuable funds. 

I have also had the privilege in my nursing career to work on a paediatric cardic intensive care unit where babies, children and young people received treatment for both congenital heart defects and cardiac disease. The BHF supports these families too.

I know these are hard times for many people, so if you are unable to do ate thank you for reading

If you can donate, that would be amazing, breaking the chocolate, crisps, sweetie habit will be hard ! Nearly stole a chocolate button off my grandson before I remembered 😂

Thanks 

Angie
title: My Dechox Fundraising Page
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
pageSummary: I am raising money because their research saves lives.
image.caption: NA
media.images.image.caption: NA

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Often there's no warning when disease takes someone's life....

21 years ago on 3rd February 2000 we lost our beloved mum to heart disease. Within a year she suffered 4 heart attacks & under went major heart surgery. If it hadn't been for the work of the BHF we would not of had our mum with us for as long as we did.

In memory of my beloved mum & the amazing work of the BHF I'm giving up chocolate & going on a DECHOX for the whole of March 2021. Please show your support dig deep & donate anything you possibly can so I can reach my target of £150.

Thank you in advance

Bal xxx

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for visiting my page.

With the Covid pandemic, physical volunteering placements were almost impossible to secure and I had to get smart about other ways to complete my Silver DoE. I am raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I’d be so grateful for your support. I am inviting you to a virtual quiz night in exchange for a donation.
title: Ewan and his magical Quiz Nights

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
I’m going to talk about something I don’t talk about a lot...

10 years ago this year I lost my dad to a heart attack. He was just 54. As a family he was a husband, dad, grandad, son, brother and uncle. 

I don’t talk about it because 10 years on, it still hurts too much. And that’s all I’m going to say.

Myself, Ian & THE KIDS are dechoxing for March - that means no chocolate for a whole month! The house has been cleared of chocolate, the kids are on board and excited to do this challenge to raise money for the British Heart Foundation.

A message from the British Heart Foundation on why they need our donations more than ever;

“The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.”
title: My Dechox Fundraising Page

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Chocolate. 

It's become a total comfort for me not just during the pandemic, but generally. My blood pressure is still too high, nine months since having a baby, my tummy is too big (according to my 4 year old yesterday) and I've realised I have a bit of a problem with my reliance on chocolate. 

This will surprise me, and probably more so my husband if I manage it. I want to combine it with increasing my exercise, to bring my BP back down - this morning it was still in the high level. I've been having regular appointments at my GP, and I've been on medication. I really don't want that to become a regular part of my life. 

If you can sponsor me, it will raise money for a good cause while I kick the cocoa habit. 

This is what BHF have to say :

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Those who know me well will know I lost my dear father very suddenly in 2019 to heart disease :( It was unknown to his family that my beautiful father suffered with any problems with his heart and it breaks mine to know that if we did know sooner, things may have been so different today. 

I have since started working in my dream job and my Daddy would be so proud of me. Pushing myself to achieve my dreams even through the worst times of my life. He is the reason I do this is because I will always strive to make him proud, to continue his legacy and to keep his memory alive. 

Carnsight Communications have turned 5 this year and to mark this amazing milestone, as a team, we have decided to take on 5 charity fundraising events. The donations will go towards two amazing charities that mean so much to us all, British Heart Foundation and Target Ovarion Cancer. 

KnowingI can help this amazing charity help others suffering silently with heart diseases makes me feel very proud. If I can offer support to anyone dealing with similar pain and struggles, I have made a little difference. 

Love you always my beautiful Daddy and I will forever do all I can to make you smile in heaven! xxxx
title: Georgia's Dechox 2021

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page, I will give you a short story on what happened to my dad and what I am doing to raise money for British Heart Foundation.

My Dad (Davy Harper) had a short lived battle with cancer of the lungs (Diagnosed Oct 2020) and was admitted into hospital on Jan 5th 2021 with difficulty breathing. At the time everyone thought the breathing difficulties had been coming from the cancer in the lungs.

Dad spent 11 days in Antrim Hospital while the doctors tried to figure out what the problem really was, the doctors came to dad on the 13th of January  asking dad "did he know he had Heart disease" This was news to my dad, as he had never shown symptoms and last he had spoke with his doctor was about a leaky valve 10 years previous but because the doctor never sent for him to have tests he assumed everything was fine.

The day of dads death my mum, sister, brother and myself had all been in touch with dad via video calls and text's. Dad seemed to be in good spirits telling me he was hoping to get home soon, My mum and dad spoke via video call at 3:15pm on the 14th January with dad still in good spirit......... at 4:20pm  mum received a call from Antrim Hospital saying my dad had died from a serious cardiac arrest at 4:10pm less than an hour after mum and dad last spoke.

The initial breathing difficulties that had my dad admitted into hospital had actually been a symptom of the heart attack.

As you can imagine, this has been complete shock and heartbreak for family, Friends and colleagues of dad but especially on my mum.

Mum and Dad had celebrated their 40th wedding anniversary just a few months before dad had been diagnosed with cancer and mum was only getting to grips with this. Then out of nowhere the love of her life is gone. 

Our team are raising funds to help BHF beat the heartbreak of heart disease. 


I have set myself a target to raise £4000 for BHF through a 460 miles cycle around Northern Ireland over 3 days, the date has still to be confirmed but it's looking more like the end of may 2022.

I have a few friends and family who will be doing the cycle with me raising funds for BHF, all donations will be sent to this page, this helps us hit our target.

I'm not expecting individuals to donate large amounts of money, even the smallest of donations help us reach target!  The old saying goes....."look after the pennies, the pounds look after themselves"

Every penny you donate helps us take one step closer to our target!

From the bottom of my heart , Thank you so much for your support, Keep an eye out on my Facebook page for updates on how we are getting on and feel free to come down and show support on the day of the event and the return leg!

Thank you!

Stewart Harper

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am running 100K in March in memory of my dad (Karl) Dad passed in December 2019 after a 14year battle with many illnesses, but the main one being heart failure which he fought with great bravery. 

Running is not my thing, but to help raise money, I'm ready for the challenge.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for visiting my page.

I'm doing this one for my great uncle John.

I'll be completing 26.2 miles of running this month which is the equivalent to a marathon.

I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives, like my uncle John, take far to soon at the age of 59. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thank you.
title: Jemma's Marathon Run

story:
Anyone who knows me, knows my love for chocolate! And in turn, know what a challenge it will be for me not to sneak spoonfuls of Nutella when no one's looking. 

Daven will be joining me as we say goodbye to chocolate, sweets and fizzy drinks for March! So pray for us. In a way, this is definitely harder than a 5k! So please sponsor us and raise some money for a great cause! 

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

charity.description: The ability to get around is vital in order to live a full life yet thousands of people with sight loss never leave home alone. We empower visually impaired people to do that and rely on the support of the public to fund the guide dog service.
charity.name: Guide Dogs
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 209617 and Scotland SC038979
story:
With the success of my walk for James Paget last year in memory of my dad I thought let's keep the positivity up and continue to support charities that my dad use to support himself. This year on the 1st of April I'm going to step up the game and push myself to cycle 100 miles for the charity guide dogs. The reason  I picked this charity because my dad helped me understand how important this charity is to people who have their sight. This charity helps those who are blind or partially blind to have a life and help those gain confidence in themselves

My aim is to raise 500 pounds but whatever the amount we make at the end  Will be going to a good cause. Remember you do not have to donate please do share this with your friends and family to help spread the love for people who have lost their sight.


Thank you so much for reading this Let the big 100 begin!

charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 209617 and Scotland SC038979
story:
Thank you for pledging your support to Pete and Kevs Birthday  challenge for 2021. On the 17th of May I will turn 72 and on the 7th of April Kev will turn 60. We are asking instead of gifts and cards this year you consider donating to our Guide Dogs challenge. We will be talking a small team of family and friends from Brownsover (Rugby) to Draycote water (Dunchurch) which is around a 15 mile walk. The charity is very close to our hearts and we have supported them for many years due to the life changing support they have given our family. The walk will take place on the Sunday 2nd of May.  

The sponsorship money you raise will truly make a difference. £140 could buy a Starter Kit for a new guide dog owner, containing everything they need to start a life with their new guide dog, this includes the iconic white harness. Its thanks to people like you that we can continue to provide life-changing services, like our guide dogs, to people with sight loss. So, a huge thank you!

If you would like to take part in our walk feel free to message one of us on facebook and we will arrange that.

story:
I’m walking in the Action Challenge Ultra Marathon Walk around the Yorkshire Dales this summer. 100km over two days in one of the most beautiful parts of the country. I’m doing it to raise funds for Guide Dogs UK - a charity whose mission I strongly believe in.

As of 2018, the average price of raising and training a guide dog was £63,000. This includes the breeding and puppy raising (also known as puppy walking), and the continual ongoing support during a dog’s working life. A guide dog owner may have as many as eight guide dogs in their lifetime bringing the total cost to around £500,000. 

A donation of £5 will help to train a puppy for a day, or perhaps you can help contribute to the cost of a harness for a working dog. Any donation will be greatly appreciated by Guide Dogs UK, and by me. I’ll endeavour to keep you all up to date with how my training goes. 

Thanks again,

Niall x

story: Great Ormond Street Hospital Childrens Charity (GOSH Charity) and McColls, the leading neighbourhood retailer, are delighted to announce a brand-new charity partnership that aims to raise £1million over the next three years. Seriously ill children from across the UK travel to Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH) for specialist treatment for rare and complex conditions. The money raised by McColls will help fund GOSH Charitys vital parent accommodation service, supporting the refurbishment of 'McColl's House', which brings families closer together when a child is receiving treatment. By partnering with GOSH Charity, McColls colleagues and customers will support families at the heart of their communities, right across the UK.

So if you can spare a bit of money to sponsor me I would really appreciate it

Thanks so much for your support.

Bella

story:
WHAT IS THE 4X4X48?

This challenge sees participants completing 4 miles (6.4K) every four hours for 48 hours (total of 48 miles), tests athletes both physically and mentally, and it’s a favourite of American ultrarunner David Goggins. David Goggins started a 4x4x48 challenge in 2020 and has continued this in 2021.

I will be completing the challenge on a rowing machine, currently situated in my living room to my wife's amusement!

My schedule is as follows:-

TimeRowMilesKMs
3/5/20218:00:00 AM146.4
12:00:00 PM2812.9
4:00:00 PM31219.3
8:00:00 PM41625.7
3/6/202112:00:00 AM52032.2
4:00:00 AM62438.6
8:00:00 AM72845.1
12:00:00 PM83251.5
4:00:00 PM93657.9
8:00:00 PM104064.4
3/7/202112:00:00 AM114470.8
4:00:00 AM124877.2


Great Ormond Street Hospital receives 237,908 outpatient visits and 43,218 inpatient visits every year (figures from 2018/19). Most of the children we care for are referred from other hospitals throughout the UK and overseas. There are 63 different clinical specialties at GOSH; the UK's widest range of specialist health services for children on one site. More than half of our patients are referred to us from outside London and a small proportion come from overseas. GOSH is the largest paediatric centre in the UK for:

  • paediatric intensive care
  • cardiac surgery - we are one of the largest heart transplant centres for children in the world
  • neurosurgery - we carry out about 60 per cent of all UK operations for children with epilepsy
  • paediatric cancer services including bone marrow transplants – with University College London Hospitals (UCLH), we are one of the largest centres in Europe for children with cancer
  • nephrology and renal transplants
  • children treated from overseas in our International and Private Patient (IPP) wing


Any little bit I can do to help support is worth the lack of sleep and bad back in my eyes.

Thank you for the support.

Will


David Goggins 4x4x48 Challenge | March 5, 2021 (gogginschallenge.com)

For more information about the work GOSH does and to find out where Team GOSH's fundraising will go visit the website: https://www.gosh.org/what-we-do

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page!

We are a group of 12 family and friends, who are getting together to complete the Three Peaks Challenge in aid of Great Ormond Street Children's Charity, to thank them for the fantastic care they have taken of Bella after being diagnosed with a Brain Tumour in September 2020. 

Bella is the happiest, sassiest 4 year old you could meet, and in September last year, she was diagnosed with an extremely large brain tumour. Rushed by ambulance to Great Ormond Street, they took the most fantastic care of her, and within days, she underwent a 7 hour brain surgery with the most incredible Neurosurgeon, in which they successfully removed the entire tumour.

Recovery for Bella was very tough. She couldn't stand/ walk, or even speak for a while, but she is as tough as they come, and is now doing fantastically well. 

Exactly one year on from Bella's diagnosis, we will be setting off to climb the three tallest peaks in the UK, all in 24hrs! A tough challenge, but nothing compared to the challenges that Bella faced after her diagnosis. 

We are all in awe of Great Ormond Street, and can never repay them for what they have done, but we hope to raise as much as we can to show our appreciation, and also make Bella proud.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Please help us to reach our target and support the amazing work that Great Ormond Street do!
title: Team Bella's National Three Peaks Challenge page

charity.description: We fundraise to enhance Great Ormond Street Hospital’s ability to transform the health and wellbeing of children and young people. Donations help to fund advanced medical equipment, child and family support services, pioneering research and rebuilding and refurbishment.
charity.name: Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity
story:
Last year I ran the Great North Run for the great people of St Cuthbert's. I did the distance in and around the hard streets of Ponteland, on my own. However my family made this day special as you can see in my picture gallery, complete with an explosive finish. 

This year I'm back baby. Ready for the REAL thing. Ready for the hallowed ground of the Central Motorway (minus the cars I hope). I'll be doing this for Great Ormond Street Hospital. A place where staff give hope and support to children and babies who need it most.

My Niece Emma spend the first few weeks of her life at Great Ormond Street Hospital and now she's growing up looking ready to take on a challenge like this herself one day soon. 

This is my way of paying back the debt I feel I owe to Great Ormond Street, going through the pain and discomfort of running in my late 30's and of course raising money. 

Here's the deal, I do the running and you give some money to families and children who need support.

charity.description: We fundraise to enhance Great Ormond Street Hospital’s ability to transform the health and wellbeing of children and young people. Donations help to fund advanced medical equipment, child and family support services, pioneering research and rebuilding and refurbishment.
charity.name: Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity
story: Every day, 619 children and young people from across the UK arrive at GOSH. Every day, doctors and nurses battle the most complex illnesses, and the brightest minds come together to achieve pioneering medical breakthroughs. And every day is a chance for you to make a difference. This extraordinary hospital has always depended on charitable support and everyone in Team GOSH taking on the iconic 2021 London Marathon will be helping to give seriously ill children the chance of a better future. For more information about the work GOSH does and to find out where Team GOSH's fundraising will go visit the website: https://www.gosh.org/what-we-do

eventName: Cycle 300 Miles for Cancer Research UK
story:
As we head in to Spring 2021, with the lighter nights and better weather fast approaching 🙏🌞 Team Buzzwork’s have decided to take on our next challenge to raise awareness and donations in aid of Cancer Research, a charity in which we know is close to many people’s hearts

The
challenge we have decided to set ourselves is the Cancer Research Cycle 300 miles (483 Kilometres) in the month of March 2021: 

🚴🚴

https://www.cancerresearchuk.org/get-involved/find-an-event/charity-challenges/cycle300?gclid=Cj0KCQiApsiBBhCKARIsAN8o_4hKZoaEjqElnc5GXW3o_VoQ4SyzHgGN7eVFSMiFn7E8aZefuzX5cXIaAroaEALw_wcB&gclsrc=aw.ds

Our team can rack up their miles in different ways throughout March, by exploring their local areas or taking part with their spin bikes at home.

We will be using our employee App to encourage each other and keep track of the total miles we cover as a team throughout March. We will be sure to post updates on this JustGiving page also 🚴🚴

Please get behind us to help raise as much money as we possibly can for a fantastic charity!!

#LETSGETPEDALLING

eventName: Growing my Hair for Cancer Research UK
story:
For those who know me, you will know how much pride and joy I get out of my hair. This all began just wanting to grow it out because I'm in my 20's, but it has turned into an idea to raise money for a charity and donate my hair at the end of it so that it can go to a person in need who would really love and benefit from it. We take our hair for granted every day and the thought of not having any makes upsets me greatly.

I have set the target for £1000, but as this is a continuous fundraiser I have no idea what we could achieve!

I take EXTREMELY great care of my hair, and I plan to keep this up as I always have. I am not sure how long I will be doing this for, but I will be going on for and long as I can!

Any donations are welcome, small or large. It is all going directly to Cancer Research UK.

Hair will be donated to The Little Princess Trust.

Thank you :)

story: After seeing similar challenges we, Nic, Em, Nic, Kat and Caroline, have decided to challenge ourselves to running, walking or moving 100KM in March. We wanted to do this for Cancer Research, every one of us in some way has been affected in our lives by cancer. Personally, I lost my fabulous father-in-law 2 years ago and the more we can learn about this horrific disease the better. Every charity needs extra support now, thanks to the lack of fundraising being able to take place during the pandemic, so this is our small way to aid them and support the amazing work these charities do. Every penny counts so please donate what you can and we will all look forward to the end of March!! Xx

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
I am running 15 miles per week throughout March to raise funds for a charity that is near to my heart, Marie Curie. I would love if anyone could donate whatever they can or wish too to encourage me to reach my target. 

From Marie Curie’s page:

“By donating to Marie Curie, you are funding care and support for people living with a terminal illness, and their families, across the UK. We believe everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel.

Everything we do depends on the generous donations of our supporters. Around two-thirds of the money we spend each year comes from the people, companies and trusts who decide to support us. The remaining third comes from the NHS.”
